Document Sources.Sourced Statement: An analysis released in August of respondents to the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey, widely seen as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender Americans, found that voting-eligible trans people had cast ballots in the last presidential election at a higher rate than the U.S. population.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The study included more than 92,000 respondents, including more than 84,000 adults who were 18 and older.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: Nearly 21 million voting-eligible U.S. citizens do not have a current driver’s license, according to the Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland, whose research was partially supported by VoteRiders.
Document Sources.Name of Source: Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland
Document Sources.Source Justification: Black and Hispanic people are among those most likely not to have a current license, so the requirement harms them too, regardless of their gender identity.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law, estimated ahead of the 2022 midterm election that more than 200,000 voting-eligible transgender Americans may find it difficult to vote at the time because of voter ID laws.
Document Sources.Name of Source: Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law
Document Sources.Source Justification: The full impact of these laws amid new and evolving voter identification laws is not yet clear, in part because of how recent they are — and that, experts say, could mask their harm.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There is a chilling effect,” said Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “A lot is falling on poll workers to correctly enforce the law,” Kunis added.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Trans votes count,” said Ankit Rastogi, director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality, which conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: The National Center for Transgender Equality conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Trans people, just like everyone else, want to be able to travel, start new jobs, open bank accounts, enroll in school, vote — all of those things require some form of ID.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lucas Cameron-Vaughn explained the challenges trans people face with identification.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It’s a tactic that’s designed to splinter support for trans rights and suggest sort of who is harmed by protecting trans people — to frame that as cisgender women being the people harmed by protections for trans people,” said Rose Saxe, who is deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Rose Saxe discussed the political tactics used against trans rights.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We saw it as a move to inflict maximum chaos and misunderstanding,” Diaz said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Diaz argued that the new gender marker regulation was designed to target transgender Floridians.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “With these laws in Florida, you’re forced to choose between living authentically and just not really participating in public life,” Diaz said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Diaz discussed the impact of Florida’s anti-trans laws.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I can imagine that a lot of trans folks in Florida who might not have access … to an accurate and affirming ID might not want to engage in that process at all, especially in such a heightened political environment,” Diaz said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Diaz discussed the challenges trans people face in Florida.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Gender nonconforming people are already under such public scrutiny nationwide,” Diaz said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Diaz discussed the scrutiny faced by gender nonconforming people.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “They won’t stop me, but I can see how it would stop others,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Hazel Krebs is a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It is almost certainly stopping some people from showing up at the polls.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Hazel Krebs is a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Something that’s very frustrating for us at VoteRiders is you will never be able to capture the number of people who do not feel safe voting, and who therefore stay home.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lauren Kunis discussed the challenges of quantifying voter suppression.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “And we know that is happening, but it is difficult to quantify.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lauren Kunis discussed the challenges of quantifying voter suppression.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There are definitely the physical dangers, the dangers for harassment, discrimination — but also ultimately, voter suppression,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lucas Cameron-Vaughn discussed the dangers faced by trans voters.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It really shows the resiliency of the trans community to ensure that our voices are heard and we have visibility at the ballot box,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director of voting and elections for the group that conducted the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Josie Caballero discussed the resiliency of the trans community.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There’s nothing these laws will do to stop me from living my best life,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Hazel Krebs is a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It just puts my energy and passion towards making this place better for me and other trans people.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Hazel Krebs is a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In Kansas, lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union have drafted a letter reminding election workers that a gender marker on a person’s identification does not need to match or correspond to a voter’s gender expression.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The ACLU is working to ensure that trans voters are not discriminated against at the polls.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In eight battleground states, the nonprofit VoteRiders is on the ground helping voters get the identification they need to cast ballots in the November election — and one that reflects who they are.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: VoteRiders is helping voters obtain identification that reflects their gender identity.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Equality Florida, the state’s leading LGBTQ+ advocacy group, is holding “know your rights” trainings in the wake of new regulations barring many transgender voters from obtaining photo identification that reflects their gender.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Equality Florida is working to educate trans voters about their rights.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The ACLU, which is tracking some of these laws and rules, has tried to prepare election workers on how to process trans voters who come into their polling sites.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The ACLU is working to ensure that trans voters are not discriminated against at the polls.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: VoteRiders is conducting year-round voter education.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: VoteRiders is helping voters obtain identification that reflects their gender identity.
